Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded primarily by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation (Germany), affords an opportunity for an international collaboration, allowing a German post-doctoral scholar to conduct research in theoretical morphosyntax at the University of Connecticut, with a research group led by Dr. Jonathan Bobaljik. The research project aims to provide a better understanding of unbalanced case forms in coordination. In major European languages, two conjoined noun phrases normally bear the same case forms - in a sentence like "The prize will be given to [us and them]," both pronouns in the bracketed expression are in the accusative form as both serve as the object of the preposition to. It is known that in many languages, only one of the noun phrases in a conjunction will bear the case form appropriate to the conjunction as a whole in this way. For example, in the Uralic language Mari, only the second noun in a conjoined object phrase bears the regular case for the syntactic context the other expression is unmarked.

While sporadic examples are known, this project on the one hand undertakes a cross-linguistic survey of these constructions (which have not been systematically surveyed in the literature) and on the other hand develops case studies of selected examples, particularly from Uralic, a theoretically rich group of understudied languages. Theoretically, the research builds on Weisser's (2014) doctoral research on asymmetries in clausal coordination, where it is argued that apparently symmetrical coordinations have an internal hierarchical structure. Research questions to be asked bear on a number of broad themes in linguistic theory including the relationship between case and agreement (asymmetries in coordination are much more well studies in agreement than in case), the role of linear order versus structure in morphological and syntactic generalizations. More broadly, by conducting a broad, cross-linguistic survey along with selected case studies informed by specific research hypotheses, the project contributes to a more refined understanding both of cross-linguistic diversity and the limits of such variation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal research goal of the project ‘Case and Coordination’ was a major cross-linguistic comparison of case marking with agreement in contexts that involve nominal conjunction. Agreement in many languages is known to show the phenomenon of Closest Conjunct Agreement. In this construction, when the subject is a coordinated phrase, such as [a dog and three cats], the verb may show singular agreement if the conjunct that is closest to the verb is singular, despite the notional plurality of the conjoined subject. The effect is robust in many languages, and for (spoken) English can be seen in contexts where speakers reliably judge constructions like (i) There is a dog and three cats in the garden to be significantly better than those like (ii) *There is three cats and a dog in the garden (Sobin 1997 Linguistic Inquiry pp. 318-343).

 

In this project, Lynen Post-Doctoral Fellow Philipp Weisser conducted a number of case studies to determine whether an analogous pattern arises for case marking in conjunctions across languages. Despite a number of alleged examples in the literature, closer investigation revealed a striking difference between case and agreement: Closest Conjunct Agreement is a robust phenomenon in many languages, but careful investigation casts doubt on whether Closest Conjunct Case exists at all. This asymmetry between case and agreement has important implications for grammatical theory. In many frameworks, it has been held that case and agreement are different formal codings of the same syntactic dependency. The striking asymmetry in the realm of coordination, not previously considered, suggests that this assumption should be reconsidered, and theories incorporating this venerable assumption should be revisited.

 

In addition to the theoretical results of the project, the goal of the Feodor Lynen Fellowship program of the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation (Germany), which provided the majority of the funding for the project, is to foster international collaboration by giving an opportunity to promising young German scholars to conduct research outside of Germany. The fellow on this project, P. Weisser, gained valuable experience in a US research environment, while student and post-doctoral members of the PI’s research team in the US were provided with an excellent opportunity for international collaborations. In addition to the individuals who participated, the project strengthened ties between research groups at the University of Connecticut and the University of Leipzig, Germany.
